entries.title: 2022 Was a Deadly Year for Journalists, Especially in Latin America
entries.description: There were nearly as many journalists killed in Mexico alone as there were in Ukraine.

entries.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine Cracks Down on Corruption
entries.description: Also, another mass shooting in California and New Zealand’s next leader.

entries.title: Juan Carrito, Italy’s Beloved Brown Bear, Dies In Traffic Accident
entries.description: The 3-year-old rare Apennine brown bear was killed Monday night. He had become a celebrity because of his forays into human habitats.

entries.title: The Sierra Club Tries to Move Past John Muir, George Floyd and #MeToo
entries.description: After a public reckoning and the departure of its executive director, the nation’s largest environmental organization has tapped Ben Jealous as its new leader.

entries.title: Pentagon Will Increase Artillery Production Sixfold for Ukraine
entries.description: The Army’s top acquisition official says production of the 155-millimeter shells badly needed by Kyiv will rise to 90,000 a month in two years.

entries.title: Chris Hipkins, New Zealand’s New Leader, Hopes to Put Ardern Behind Him
entries.description: Mr. Hipkins, who will be sworn in this week, has nine months to persuade voters who cooled on Jacinda Ardern’s government that he’s a fresh alternative.

entries.title: Germany Says It Will Make a Decision Soon on Sending Leopard 2 Tanks to Ukraine
entries.description: Kyiv has been pleading for months for hundreds of modern battle tanks to reinforce its battered Soviet-era fleet.

entries.title: The firings come amid a ballooning corruption scandal involving military procurement.
Unions and Video Games
entries.description: Gaming is a huge industry, and workers are trying to unionize.

entries.title: 2 More Ukrainian Officials Are Removed From Posts Amid Corruption Crackdown
entries.description: Officials in the Defense Ministry and the prosecutor general’s office were dismissed. President Volodymyr Zelensky announced a ban on unofficial trips.

entries.title: A Dilemma for Governments: How to Pay for Million-Dollar Therapies
entries.description: A wave of transformative but hugely expensive treatments is challenging the budgets of health systems in wealthy nations. Now countries with far fewer resources are wrestling with how to cover the therapies.

entries.title: Can Germany Be a Great Military Power Again?
entries.description: Leery of Russian aggression, Europe’s economic giant is making a historic attempt to revitalize its armed forces. It has a long way to go.

entries.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
entries.description: Seven killed in another mass shooting in California.

entries.title: Russia’s War Breathes Life Into Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty
entries.description: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, a news network originally set up as a C.I.A. operation early in the Cold War, is experiencing a renaissance and making a case for its independence.
